discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Would you spend 70,000 MKR to get rid of the USDC?

content.content: I know this has been asked before and rejected, but I think we’re in a different spot now so I’d like to take the community’s temperature. I arrived at the number (70k) because at todays prices it would allow the DAO to pay roughly 3% on the current Dai supply. To be clear, this Dai would be paid to Vault users that mint Dai, not on Dai itself. It would increase our market share (by effectively causing the USDC in Maker to be redeemed or increasing the total amount of Dai generated) and remove the existential risk/PR issues. The downside, of course, is that (a) it may not work as intended and (b) it dilutes MKR holders. It also wouldn’t permanently solve the problem, it would just buy us more time to do something like refinancing into Real World Assets at scale. We’d also still likely have some USDC in the system given the current growth rate of Dai demand, but it would hopefully be an inconsequential amount. I’m bringing this up now because there’s been a lot of creative solutions thrown around to “quickly” achieve this goal, and while they’re interesting and should potentially be pursued in parallel, I think we should rule out the simplest method first if we’re going to devote resources to this.    Would you spend 70,000 MKR to (hopefully) get rid of the USDC?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters

content.content: I really think we’re missing the boat if we view all this USDC as something to get rid of as soon as possible. I’d love to see it be a much smaller percentage of DAI backing, But this is literally money we are being paid to hold and are not charged interest. We can find ways to swap some it or get yield on it or simply grow the total portfolio to lessen its impact. I certainly don’t think we should pay money to offload it.

content.content: This feels like a nuclear option. I don’t like the reliance on USDC, but it’s also the case that if USDC goes under, then DeFi more broadly will be a radioactive wasteland. I’d really like to explore the idea of paying part of liquidation fees to Vault holders, now that Liq2.0 makes auctions more efficient. It wouldn’t be as much as you’re suggesting, making it more of a lottery (a BT or Scary Wednesday-type event might wipe out some users’ fees entirely), but it’s another tool to explore.

content.content: I think vaultholder incentives are necessary in an environment where the system’s natural market incentive to mint dai for speculative purposes (i.e. via a high peg) have been dampened by other forces. I suspect there’s some novelty and dry powder on the sidelines that would enter at much smaller incentive rates, say 0.5%, which would be paid for out of the stability fees we’re charging. It would result in a lower return for MKR holders for sure, but I wouldn’t frame it as MKR lost any more than I’d frame reducing rates as MKR lost. It’s just where the market is at. I think of this as the missing “Dai Generation Rate” that would complement the “Dai Savings Rate” at the other side of the peg. Anyways, It’s not necessary to go entirely out of pocket to provide some incentive for vaultholders so I don’t really agree with the way that this is worded. If MKR holders are willing to do “whatever it takes” to maintain the Dai peg, I don’t see how vaultholder incentives as a solution are any more extreme than taking on billions in regulated stablecoins.

content.content: I voted abstain because the amount is probably too high and the reward should be directed to some key vault such as eth-c or eventually uni dai pair. Let’s be honest we are in a market where competitors are rewarding we probably need to have this tool in place. Compound just launches its new feature. We won’t last long if we are just accumulating usdc and dai. Also the last big up was triggered by curve and compound. If no one is doing anything it is not going to bring more people into defi and dai supply won’t increase. Most importantly, when a dollar is bringing into Ethereum it rarely leaves therefore if more people are coming we are also building our future. Think about Ford. Note: I am not 100% convinced but I am more and more accepting it. Interestingly at the end I am ending accepting all @brianmcmichael ideas .
